What is dry skin and how should I care for it?

## Dry Skin

Dry skin produces less natural oil and often feels tight or flaky. It may have a rough texture or fine cracks, especially in low humidity.

## Recommended Routine

Use a gentle, cream-based cleanser that won't strip away moisture. Apply a rich moisturizer (oil-in-water emulsions like lotions, gels, or serums that hydrate) right after cleansing, and reapply as needed. Always use a broad-spectrum sunscreen SPF 30+ daily (ideally a moisturizing formula). Choose a moisturizing makeup or primer base if you wear makeup. Dry skin benefits from occasional gentle exfoliation (e.g. a mild AHA) to remove flaky cells, but always follow with moisturizer to prevent irritation.

## Additional Tips

Avoid long, hot showers which can further dry out skin; use a humidifier in dry climates. Look for ingredients like hyaluronic acid, glycerin, ceramides, and natural oils in products to help retain moisture. Use fragrance-free products if prone to eczema or sensitivity.

What is oily skin and how should I care for it?

## Oily Skin

Oily skin produces excess sebum, leading to a shiny appearance and enlarged-looking pores, especially in the T-zone. It may be prone to acne and blackheads.

## Recommended Routine

Cleanse gently twice a day with a water-soluble cleanser that removes oil without over-drying (avoid harsh, alcohol-based cleansers). After cleansing, you can apply any acne treatments or toners as needed. Use a lightweight, oil-free moisturizer (yes, even oily skin needs moisture) â€“ ideally one with broad-spectrum SPF 30 for daytime. If your moisturizer doesn't have SPF, apply a separate non-comedogenic sunscreen. Opt for matte, water-based makeup if you use it, to avoid adding shine or oil. Oily skin can benefit from exfoliation 1-2 times a week (for example, a salicylic acid product) to keep pores clear, but don't overdo it and always moisturize after exfoliating.

## Additional Tips

Blotting papers or a light dusting of powder can help manage midday shine. Non-comedogenic ("won't clog pores") products are essential. Avoid scrubbing skin harshly; it won't reduce oil and can irritate skin into producing more oil. Consistent, gentle care will balance oil production better in the long run.

What is combination skin and how should I care for it?

## Combination Skin

Combination skin has both oily and dry areas (commonly an oily forehead/nose/chin with drier cheeks). Different parts of the face have different needs.

## Recommended Routine

Treat each area appropriately: apply oil-absorbing, mattifying products only on oily zones (e.g. T-zone), and use richer creams or hydrating serums only on dry patches. Use a gentle cleanser that cleans oily areas without over-drying the dry parts. Opt for fragrance-free, alcohol-free toners and avoid irritating ingredients, since both oily and dry areas can react poorly to harsh products. Use a non-comedogenic lotion for overall hydration â€“ apply a lighter layer on oily parts and a heavier layer on dry parts. Sunscreen should be lightweight (gel or fluid) to avoid greasiness in oily areas; you can even use a matte finish sunscreen on the T-zone. If needed, you might use two different moisturizers (an oil-free one for oily areas, a creamier one for dry areas). Adjust your routine as your skin changes â€“ for example, in humid weather you may need less moisturizer, whereas in winter you may need more on dry areas.

## Additional Tips

Precision is key: some people "multi-mask" by applying a clay mask only on oily areas and a hydrating mask on dry areas. Avoid over-layering too many products on the entire face; instead, target application by zone. Make sure all products are gentle and avoid excessive fragrance or alcohol which can aggravate both dryness and oiliness. Using a gentle chemical exfoliant (like a glycolic acid) occasionally can help keep skin balanced, but be sure to moisturize any dry areas immediately afterward.

What is sensitive skin and how should I care for it?

## Sensitive Skin

Sensitive skin is easily irritated by products or environmental factors. It may itch, burn, or get red and stinging when certain cosmetics or skincare products are applied. This skin type often overlaps with conditions like rosacea, eczema, or allergies.

## Recommended Routine

Simplify your routine: use as few products as possible and choose those with gentle, minimal ingredients. A mild, fragrance-free, hypoallergenic cleanser and a bland moisturizer (with no perfumes or common irritants) are key. Avoid products with alcohol, artificial fragrance, or harsh exfoliants. Always patch-test new products on a small area of skin before using them broadly. Apply a moisturizer twice a day to help strengthen the skin barrier and reduce reactivity. Sunscreen is important (sensitive skin still needs UV protection), but use physical filters like zinc oxide or titanium dioxide, or sunscreens specifically labeled for sensitive skin to minimize chances of irritation. Introduce any active ingredients (like retinol or vitamin C) very slowly, in low concentrations, and if irritation occurs, discontinue use.

## Additional Tips

Look for labels such as "for sensitive skin" or "dermatologist tested," but still scrutinize the ingredient list â€“ the shorter, the better. Often, simple products like pure aloe vera gel or products with colloidal oatmeal can soothe sensitive skin. If a product causes burning or redness, wash it off and stop using it. In general, less is more â€“ stick to basic cleansing, moisturizing, and sun protection. If you have a condition like rosacea or persistent dermatitis, consult a dermatologist for tailored guidance.

What is normal skin and how should I care for it?

## Normal Skin

Normal skin is well-balanced â€“ not too oily or too dry, with few sensitivities or blemishes. Pores are generally small, skin texture is smooth, and the skin doesn't produce excess shine or flakes.

## Recommended Routine

Normal skin benefits from a consistent basic routine to maintain its health. Cleanse with a gentle face wash to remove impurities without stripping moisture. Use a light moisturizer to keep skin hydrated and support the barrier. Apply broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher) every morning to prevent cumulative sun damage. Normal skin can generally tolerate a wider range of products, so you can incorporate serums (like a vitamin C antioxidant serum in the morning) or a mild retinol at night for preventive care against aging, but introduce them one at a time to ensure your skin tolerates them. Exfoliate periodically (for instance, once a week) with a gentle scrub or AHA to maintain radiance and smooth texture, but avoid over-exfoliating which could disrupt the skin's balance.

## Additional Tips

Even normal skin can have occasional minor issues (like a random pimple or a bit of dullness), so adjust your routine if needed â€“ for example, do an extra clay mask if you get a little oily in the T-zone in summer, or use a richer moisturizer if your skin gets drier in winter. Continue healthy lifestyle habits (good diet, hydration, not smoking, managing stress) to support your skin's condition. Essentially, protect the skin from damage and don't neglect daily care, even if it appears "low-maintenance."

## Hyperpigmentation

Hyperpigmentation refers to patches of skin that become darker than the surrounding area due to excess melanin. Examples include post-acne dark spots (post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation), sun spots (age spots), or melasma (brown patches often due to hormonal changes). This issue can affect all skin tones, though dark spots may persist longer and be more noticeable on medium to deep skin tones.

## How to Manage Hyperpigmentation

Sun protection is the foundation of treating hyperpigmentation. Daily use of broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher) prevents spots from darkening and new ones from forming. Dermatologists often recommend a tinted sunscreen with iron oxide for skin of color, as it protects against visible light which can worsen melasma and dark spots. Wear sun-protective clothing and seek shade, since even brief sun exposures accumulate. To fade existing hyperpigmentation, incorporate topical ingredients that brighten skin and/or slow melanin production: vitamin C, niacinamide, azelaic acid, kojic acid, glycolic or lactic acid (AHAs), and retinoids are all options proven to help. Over-the-counter serums or creams with these ingredients, used consistently, can gradually lighten dark spots over a period of months. Consistency is key â€“ it often takes 8-12 weeks (or longer) to see noticeable improvement, and deeper discoloration can take 6-12 months or more to fade significantly. Avoid harsh scrubs or irritants that could inflame the skin, as new irritation can trigger more pigmentation. If OTC products aren't sufficient, a dermatologist can offer stronger treatments like prescription hydroquinone, tretinoin, chemical peels, or laser therapy to break up pigment. But even with treatments, continuing strict sun protection is crucial to prevent recurrence.
